details.source_text: BEIJING ï¿½ As mainland China relaxes many of its stringent Covid controls, analysts point out the country is far from a quick return to a pre-pandemic situation.
details.reused_text: The arrangements highlight how lingering anxieties created by Beijingï¿½s three-year ï¿½zero-COVIDï¿½ policy are likely to hamper a quick return to health for the worldï¿½s second-largest economy, despite its pivot away from strict containment measures.

details.source_text:
The path forward for China to reopen may take a few months, with a surge in infections likely, according to a Goldman Sachs report on Dec. 4.

ï¿½With most of the population uninfected before reopening, lower elderly vaccination rates than many other economies, and cultural similarities, we think Hong Kong and Taiwanï¿½s reopenings are most relevant for Mainland China,ï¿½ said chief China economist Hui Shan and a team.

details.source_text: Looking ahead, itï¿½s pretty clear that Chinaï¿½s Covid policy is about to cross a turning point, said Bruce Pang, chief economist and head of research for Greater China at JLL.

They expect any initial reopening to create a drag on the economy ï¿½due to surging infections, a temporary shortage of labor supply and increased supply chain disruptions.ï¿½

Goldman forecasts 3% growth for Chinaï¿½s economy this year, and 4.5% in 2023.
